intro: Maerua kassakalla, commonly known as the African bushwillow, is a shrub or small tree native to the dry regions of Africa. It belongs to the family Capparaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant is adapted to arid environments, with deep roots that help it access groundwater. Its bark is often used in traditional medicine, and it plays a role in preventing soil erosion. Maerua kassakalla is also a valuable source of fodder for livestock in semi-arid areas.
